documentType: Bureau of Prisons internal memorandum and psychological reconstruction report
summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons psychological reconstruction report on the suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The report details his background, institutional history, mental health assessments, and the circumstances leading to his death, concluding with operational recommendations. This document is a portion of an internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) report reviewing the circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details numerous procedural failures, documentation inaccuracies, and lapses in protocol related to suicide watch, inmate monitoring, staff training, and record-keeping.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at approximately 6:33 a.m. and was pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey upon his return from Paris, France, and transported to MCC New York.

events.title: First Suicide Incident
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell with a piece of orange cloth around his neck, resulting in him being placed on suicide watch. He denied it was a suicide attempt and suggested his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Bail Denial
events.description: Judge Richard M. Berman denied Epstein's request for bail and pretrial release, detailing the danger he posed and alleging he was a flight risk.

events.title: Court Documents Unsealed
events.description: Approximately 2,000 pages of documents, including graphic allegations against Epstein and naming other high-profile figures, were unsealed and released to the public.

events.title: Florida Plea Agreement
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty to one count of Solicitation of Prostitution and one count of Procuring a Person Under the Age of 18 for Prostitution in Florida, receiving an 18-month sentence.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York with abrasions on his neck and knee. Conflicting descriptions exist about what was around his neck.

events.title: Epstein on Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was placed on suicide watch after being found unresponsive. During this time, required continuous observation was not maintained, especially during lengthy attorney visits.

events.title: Unmonitored Phone Call
events.description: Epstein terminated a legal visit to place a telephone call. He was escorted to the SHU shower area and, lacking his PIN, a Unit Manager dialed a number (area code 347) for him. Epstein claimed he was calling his deceased mother.

events.title: Initial Mental Health Concern
events.description: Upon arrival at MCC New York, a Facility Assistant observed Epstein as "distraught, sad and a little confused" and emailed staff recommending a psychologist speak with him, but required follow-up did not occur.

events.title: Bail Denied
events.description: Epstein was denied bail, which the report notes was a significant disappointment likely challenging his ability to adapt to incarceration.

events.title: Inconclusive SIS Assessment
events.description: A Special Investigative Services Threat Assessment was completed but was inconclusive as to whether Epstein's injuries were from self-harm, a fight with his cellmate, or an assault by his cellmate.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide on August 10, 2019, while in federal custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.
The reconstruction report notes the absence of key evidence, including video footage confiscated by the FBI and the inability to conduct formal interviews due to pending DOJ investigations.
Epstein had a prior incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a cloth around his neck; he denied it was a suicide attempt and claimed his cellmate tried to kill him.
On the night of his death, Epstein was single-celled because his cellmate did not return from court, and staff failed to complete required 30-minute rounds at 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m.
The report concludes that factors contributing to Epstein's suicide included the loss of his status, lack of deep interpersonal connections, and the prospect of life in prison.

There were significant inconsistencies in the documentation of the scene when Epstein was found unresponsive on July 23, 2019, with one report mentioning a "string" and another a "piece of handmade orange cloth" around his neck.
Critical procedural failures occurred, including a lack of continuous observation during Epstein's suicide watch, especially during marathon attorney visits totaling over 60 hours in one week.

Record-keeping was severely flawed: suicide watch logs were improperly altered, inmate housing assignments in SENTRY were inaccurate, and attorney log books were unsecured and contained numerous errors after Epstein's death.
Epstein was allowed to make an unmonitored phone call on August 9, 2019, where a staff member dialed a number for him (area code 347) after he claimed he was calling his deceased mother.
The report highlights a systemic lack of understanding and management of sex-offender risk factors among staff and multiple instances where psychological protocols and alerts were not followed.
